title: Squid Game
review: Squid Game is absolutely worth the watch. It is fascinating, exciting and at times moving. The first and currently only season is highly suited for a proper binging session, as the conclusion of each episode will leave you wondering what will happen next, and where all of this will ultimately go. Sadly, the pay-off is not as grand as we are led to believe.The visual presentation of Squid Game is wonderfully surreal. Endless staircases, pastel colors and trick doors make the entrance to the game area seem like a demented funhouse designed by M. C. Escher. The facility is guarded by ominous masked figures in bright pink jumpsuits, and the game areas themselves are nightmarish visions of children's playgrounds. This gives the entire series an uncanny, oppressive atmosphere throughout all nine episodes. In terms of set design, costume design and overall visual presentation, Squid Game could not have done much better.However, the narrative that unfolds against this otherworldly backdrop is not always as coherent or fleshed-out as the perfectly composed environments would suggest.Squid Game is a variation of the concept of a 'death game', which has been seen many times before in productions such as Running Man and Hunger Games.Series director and writer Hwang Dong-hyuk adds variation to this familiar concept by emphasizing the voluntary nature of the game: each contestant has to apply themselves in order to join the game, and even after they have been sedated and kidnapped to the island where the games are to take place, they are given ample opportunity to leave and return to their normal lives.The game rules even include the option to halt the games at any time, should a majority of the contestants vote to do so. In episode 2, this is exactly what ends up happening. The episode then goes on to try and establish that, despite the horrors of these murderous children's games, the normal lives of the participants are so dire and hopeless that they cannot but conclude that game is the lesser of two evils, and by the end of the episode, 93% of the original surviving players have returned to continue the game. This is an impossible idea to sell to an audience, even when the pool of contestants is supposed to consist of the country's most desperate and indebted.Fantastical premise aside, the way the actual games play out will leave you with sweaty palms more than once. In addition to its presentation, another strong point of the series is feeding us information and letting us try and puzzle it together before feeding us answers. The behavior and motivation of certain characters and even major plot points can be figured out well in advance if you know what to look for and how to piece it all together. This adds an extra layer of tension to the already nerve-wrecking death games.Although the series eventually goes out of its way to answer some of the most pressing questions, there is occasional room for speculation. Was Sang Woo a humble man who got corrupted by his desperation to win the game, only to find back his humanity at the very end? Or was he a cold and calculating cutthroat who was planning to abuse the trust of others from the get-go, ultimately taking his own life simply because he refused to go back to his miserable life?Squid Game could have benefitted from leaving more of such questions open to the interpretation of the viewer. The most glaring example of this is the mystery surrounding the VIPs who view and fund these games, which was decisively shattered by the absolutely horrid actors who played them, clumsily delivering dialogue so juvenile that you couldn't get away with it in a Call of Duty voice lobby.Similarly, the big reveal at the end, that the old man was the mastermind behind it all, might have been best left to fan speculation. Not only does this Scooby Doo-like villain reveal feel cheap, predictable and too on-the-nose, but when the character is asked about his motivation for the game, the answer reveals how downright shallow the plot can be on occasions. The old man, who is on his deathbed, reveals that the game was put together to provide excitement to himself and his exorbitantly rich friends. Perverted elites paying to see poor, desperate people die for their own twisted entertainment was my first guess upon learning the show's premise, and it was truly disappointing to see that my surface-level observation proved to be all there was to it.That all being said, most of the acting, pacing and visualization of Squid Game do carry the series to great heights. When it's good, it really is good. Particular praise has to go to HoYeon Jung. In what is reportedly her major acting debut, she excellently portrays Kang Sae-byeok, who is perhaps one of the only truly likeable characters playing the game, as she is one of the few contestants not stupid, a backstabber or both. The North Korean defector, who hopes to win the money to help her mother, who still lives in her home country, and her orphaned brother. Sae-byeok wears her cold, almost ruthless disposition as her armor, but ultimately shows more humanity than most of the other contestants, even breaking down completely when her opponent in the marble game throws the match to guarantee Sae-byeok's survival. These shifts in her personality, both sudden and gradual, are given immense weight by the actress's performance, and it's in moments like these that the series truly shines.There can be little doubt that Squid Game is an entertaining, addictive watch. Ultimately though, its inconsistency does end up harming it. The series might hit a home run in one area, but then completely drop the ball in the next. As a viewer, you are left wondering where it all goes, trusting that all these plot points which the creators dangle in front of you will ultimately pay off. In the end, the series is like the giant piggy bank full of money that perpetually hovers over the contestants' heads in the sleeping area. After the violence is over and the dust settles, you get what you expected, but you're still left with a feeling of emptiness.

title: Squid Game
review: Such a blatant rip off. Just watch the anime or read the manga, u will get it. The plot, the MC all remain the same. They just tweeked the events a bit to call it "squid game" and not "kaiji ultimate warrior: live action adaptation". Netflix has launched many anime adaptation, but all of them have failed every single time - Erased, Bleach, Death Note(why??), because in each of them they changed the story, skipped events and trashed the anime. Now they have done the same thing by just changing the name of the adaptation. Hats off to the brilliant plagiarisers of Netflix, may your dumb and clueless customers yield you tons of profit.

title: Squid Game
review:
Visually appealing and memorable design, nice sets
Not "original" or "A new" in the long established death game/survival genre. "drew inspiration" by copy-pasting and tweaking some parts from different shows/mangas like kaiji (gambler &the glass numbered game) and liar game and made it its own.Simple and appealing approach to be marketable to the mainstreamtakeaway: would probably remember it as the "shapes" and "in red suits cooking in aprons" "suit red blue envelope at train station" "playground painted wall" show etc =so, visuals. But the characters or their backstories not so much, it would be broadly "in the death game genre" around the same time jp ver of cube comes out 2021/2022.

title: Squid Game
review: This is a gripping, bingeable series. Without a doubt. It is fast-paced and builds anticipation throughout.But once the mystery fades, we see a pretty shallow set-up. Promising character development ultimately does not hold up, with some making seemingly inexplicable (but plot advancing) decisions. Other supporting characters have absolutely no-depth at all to the point of being gratingly inhuman. Other reviewers compare it to anime/cartoon. I agree.In the end, there are enough open questions to support a second season but unfortunately not enough resolution in the first season to feel we really got the payoff we needed for putting up with all that violence.

title: Squid Game
review: This series is the prime example of the most prevalent problem in the Korean entertainment industry as a whole, tho I can argue the same for A LOT MORE.It is the simple: Insane budget for marketing and enormous effort for the outside coat of paint(which is in no way bad) but not nearly enough care for the actual content.Like seriously, the protagonist is just horribly writen in general. From start to finish, everything. If you view him through the Asian lens and especially regards to ethics, it gets even worse. You can clearly see how they try to make him a flawed character that would grow out of his bad habits but thanks to terrible ways of handling, he came of as simultaneously UNLIKABLE and FAKE. His introduction is horrible and his "development" is so illogical that erasing the attempt of the writers from your memory is much easier than acknowledging it and forcefully thinking "At least they tried".If the protagonist is that bad, you can imagine how the rest of the cast is handled. Basically just walking tropes that every survival game has with little to no meaningful gimmick attached, yet still badly presented.The games are just real life ones teleported into the show's world with a single additional rule of "Losing means death". While it works in favor of mass appeal and excite the "what if I was there" curiosity, the thrill fades fairly quickly due to the simplicity, not helped by the fact that the methods to gain advantages in them are all too well known as well, maybe with the exception of the first. In case those aren't bad enough, the amount of luck occurred to pull the protagonist out of trouble is enough to win the lottery for life.Yet, as I laid out at the beginning, this show is beautiful. From the set design and vfx to the acting, very few mishandles, tho are pretty glaring when they do occur. But overall, incredible. Wish they gave that level of attention to the script as well.In short, gorgeous look, empty soul.

title: Squid Game

title: Squid Game
review: First it looked very exciting and fresh content for netflix shows, the first game was amazing but then the following games were quite boring except game 4. The stories about characters were SO BORING, i could not watch most of the storylines about them. The lines were too long and boring and unrelated as well. Police thing was very exciting but then what? He killed by his brother who is the manager of the games(!) and nothing clarified?? Who is he? Why is he the manager of the games? As a watcher, it did not give me the answers so it was a wasted storyline too. And i do not even wanna talk about VIPs and their lines...they were horrible. And the ending, why did you go back? What about your beloved daughter?what about your promises?Besides all of these bad comments, it was a unique show and some scenes were very exciting than i could not even blink. title: Squid Game
review: .It took me a while to finish this series but overall I liked it. I think most people know the premise of the story, but i think the competition and games are not the most important part of the series, but the social critique of capitalism, greed, selfishness and people's lack of empathy and solidarity and also, it has good character development and we stick to some of them.In relation to the technical parts i think they will border the perfection and we see the passion and care with the serie.However, the series has negative points, such as ease of scripting and predictable parts, plot twist without sense and forced and halfway through the series it took time to unravel the story, but nothing that spoils the experience.I highly recommend this series for those who haven't seen it and that this series is a door for many people who are still kind of prejudiced with films, series, etc. From cultures other than English or American, which I understand and that I am sometimes, but it is necessary to deconstruct these ideas and see that there is more outside our comfort zone.

title: Squid Game
review: Squid Game has one of the most incredible and unimaginable plots I have ever seen, it starts off with introducing the main character and his primary conflicts in life and how later on he is introduced to the game where he meets several other players to win the cash prize of a 46.5 billion. I wouldn't particularly call this show a masterpiece but it is quite near the mark, it truly depicts of how far humans go can to the deepest extent for their personal gain, the acting is outstanding and exceptional, it is so exquisite that you can feel the character's emotion running through your mind. Each episode just increases your curiosity more and more, that's what makes it extremely interesting, all together it was a meaningful series , the series started of exceptionally good however the ending is something which isn't satisfying at least in my opinion, you can watch and find out for yourself. Although I don't prefer watching Korean content , this is surely one of the reasons I would love to explore more Korean content.

This has all been done better elsewhere.

title: Squid Game
review: Beginning was amazing. However, the sanctimony and dreariness of the main character made it increasingly more difficult to watch. Kang Sae-byeok, for example, would've made a far superior main character. Then, VIPs we're utterly disappointing. What was even the point of Jun Ho, other than being a filler?! Also, this secret organization kidnaps and murders 456 Koreans annually in a very short and specific period of time, yet no one ever notices? Altogether, the concept has potential, but the obvious threads to Saw franchise and insufferable main character just didn't do it for me.

title: Squid Game
review: I see a lot of shows like this that start with a good idea but often fizzle out by resorting to common dystopian clichés like forgettable actors and leads, predictable plot lines and character choices, and the like.I was pleasantly surprised by Squid Game! It engages lots of different subplots in addition to the main game, and manages to make each one very invested and entertaining. If you're someone who wants some fresh takes on the thriller/dystopian scene, pick this show! It'll keep you gripping your seat, theorizing with your friends about who will live and who will die, in and out of the game itself. I had so much fun with this show and recommend it to any group of morbidly curious friends.

title: Squid Game
review: Since in late 2021 its been a popular conventional in everyone's mouth that a korean web series goes stupendous success in drama genre. I don't know or rather don't like series type movies so, i didn't saw that on purpose. Later i want to know what games present in this movies that pubg added their events. A curiosity grown in my mind after i watched the deady game red light green light, that gives me more interesting to watch this web series.In February after download 4 episode i start watching, firstly i got very amazed and scared after finish 1st episode. Then i saw how people become a slaves to money in 2nd epi. After i downloaded full season. In this way i really enjoyed this web series upto episode 5.But before i ended episode 6, it give me a heart touching moment that fells me very emotional. The character's sense of humanity, betrayal, sacrifices all are potrayed in one game. Seriously i was cried very much at that moment and became so emotional that i couldn't think about anything eles for few days.....literally. I only thought about the situation that was passed through the characters and the whole world seemed shut to me. I thought i can't watch this far more because my heart has broken into pieces :( . Then after a week i again start watching, thought in mind that whatever it would be i will finish it untill i come to the conclusion.In episode 8 there was another betrayal and saddest moment where a cute, innocent girl got killed by the main character's friend which was very unexpected. Personally I was not gave much attention for that character from the beginning but when she was in danger and finally got killed i became very sentimental for her. I felt so much sorrow and pain for the character and eventually this sorrow and pain grows love for the character. I love kang sae-byeok also the actress who potrayed the character Jung HoYeon <3 . I love the character kang sae-byeok at first but now i love hoooooyeony, who portrayed the character, more than anyone. The series ends in episode 9 reveals the winner of this game and what changes occur in the character's life.......and there should be a sequel that officially announced by squid game producers where we found the main purpose of making this game and reveals who's the mastermind of it.At last my conclusion is that.... It was one of the best web series in Netflix ever......you've ever seen before. I've never seen a web series before but after this I don't think there could be a better series like this ever made before in the world. This squid game was planned in 2008 by its director Hwang Dong-hyuk, and due his vigorous effort its series has been executed for long 13 years. Every characters has their tragedic flaws which will make their downfall in this play. All the character have their own reason for their death. If you carefully watch, you'll notice it.For all this reason i preferred and appreciate this Web Series and give it 10 out of 10 ratings.Thank You.

title: Squid Game
review: Really good show, until the VIPs show up in episode 7. Worst acting I've ever seen. It's like the director doesn't understand English himself and hired random American guys off the street. It doesn't ruin the show, but it's so bad. In general though this is definitely worth a watch.

title: Squid Game
review: I feel like this is one of those shows that went viral and it's not entirely clear why. The show is good, but nothing so exceptional that it deserves this kind of attention. In my opinion the actors, sound and cinematography are all great and I enjoyed their delivery.The writing on the other hand, is a pretty mixed bag. For example, the show's only subplot (that gets may 20-30% of screentime) has no impact on the main plot and then later resolves itself with a really underwhelming twist. Why did they even bother including it? In general, there are too many senseless twists towards the end that lessen the characters and series.Then there's the rather cliché "rich people pitting poor people against each other" setting. They make the rich villains so cartoonishly evil, that I can't take them seriously. Especially their "69" jokes sound like they were written by a 12-year old on 9GAG.My gripes with the writing aside, I think it was still an interesting watch. There are also some really obvious hints that the show is looking to make a sequel, so maybe the creators can write something more nuanced then.

title: Squid Game
review: "Squid Game" is a very interesting and enjoyable show that everyone can relate to. If I had to describe it in three words it would be money, life and death. All of these are universal which makes it very easy for anyone to understand what the story is about and why the characters act like they do.The main character Gi-Hun is a 48 year old miserable gambling addict who lives at home with his mother. While she works to provide for the family, an already in debt Gi-Hun gladly plans to gamble away the money he got to buy a present for his own daughter on her birthday. When things don't work out he is offered to earn some money by playing a kid's game and it quickly escalates to him joining a tournament of six games based in an unknown location with 455 other people. In there he meets up with the rest of the characters: Sang-Woo, Ali, Sae-byeok and Il-nam. One thing they all have in common is that they are in need of money. Sang-Woo needs money so he can pay a bet he made where he lost everything, Ali because he has a family back in Pakistan that needs providing and Sae-byeok because she wants to take custody of her brother. The only one who doesn't play the game for economical reasons is Il-nam. The old man has a tumor in his brain and feels like it's a waste of time just laying around and waiting to die.As the plot continues the characters get the hang of the games and understand that if you lose you'll be "eliminated" (in other words dead). After the first game panic breaks out and the survivors call for a vote so they can leave if they want. The result of the vote is a 50/50 with only Il-nam left. He finally decides to vote "NO" and they all leave with a promise that they can return if a majority wishes to. Back in their normal lives they realize that it's not much better outside and most of the contenders want to return. While this is happening, Jun-ho, a cop in search of his brother, discreetly sneaks on a boat on its way to the location of the games. At the island a lot of things happen but his storyline doesn't really lead anywhere and it's very separated from the main plot with it mainly focusing on giving the viewer a picture of the games backstage. I have read reports that state this was a forced last minute addition by Netflix which would explain this part.When the games get going you can see the real personalities of the characters flourish. Our protagonist pretty much stays the same throughout the entire show, same goes for Ali, Il-nam and Sae-byeok. Sang-Woo, on the other hand, will change a lot which is an interesting view on their situation. The others want to win together while Sang-Woo is determined to win no matter the cost, and this will be a crucial factor in a few of his drastic choices. Gi-Hun might want the best for everyone, but is the morally right decision always the right decision? Personally I understand both ways of thinking.I think the setting was unsettling because of the playful and bright colours. Hundreds of people play children's games in a very "happy" environment but then find out that if you lose, you die. It can be very disturbing for one to connect a childish atmosphere with blood and death, for the actual characters it must have been disturbing as well. The music can be found unsettling for the viewer in a very similar way to the environment because of the playfulness. Another thing I noticed is that they never give an overhead view of the city in the first episode which can give a feeling of claustrophobia and I think this is a metaphor for the situation our characters are in; to not have a choice but to continue the games. In the last episode we are shown a few views of skyscrapers and the city as a whole which might give you the feeling that it's over, but at what cost?Many will say that the twist at the end was a bad move, but after watching the show for a second time I discovered that we are handed out hints almost all the time. Il-nam talks a lot about his childhood and how the food they are served and the neighborhood in one of the games are identical to what he experienced as a youngster. Why he voted "NO" in the poll is because the plan always was for them to join voluntarily which says a lot about his ambitions. He also didn't lie about his reasoning for playing the games, the story stayed true to itself from start to end.There are parts of the show where stereotypes play a big part which is one of the negatives. Ali, the only non-Korean character, is the person to get fooled in the most important moment of his life. He is also always the one who needs explaining about the games. The likelihood that it just happens to be an odd one out who is treated this way is very low. Another part where the show generalizes people is when we are introduced to the rich american VIP-audience. This is very excessive and even if they are bad people, I doubt they would act like they do (not even mentioning their horrible acting). Maybe it wasn't on purpose but a show this big will send a message that maybe wasn't supposed to be sent.Since it has become known worldwide, maybe it will create a bridge between Korean movies and viewers from the rest of the world. Sharing cultures and different languages can be an interesting view for many. Personally I would like the story to end here so it stays a Korean classic and doesn't end up a victim of its own success. Another season would come with very high expectations and I don't think Netflix will stop the production of their most mainstream show ever until it's dead and buried.In conclusion, this show has its flaws but also its moments. Some of the acting is horrendous but the majority is very honest and you really get a connection to most of the characters. The stereotypes and the subplot are probably the worst parts about this show, but it doesn't overshadow all the good things. When you know what these characters are here for, the environment and music makes you feel for them even more. I also really like how the contenders begin to show their real selves when the survival instinct kicks in and how their mindsets change throughout the show. It also has a lot of cool shots and is overall just a great experience to live through. "Squid Game" is a great show that I would recommend to anyone.

review: Squid Game is one of the most interesting and gripping shows I've watched in a while. It grabbed my attention and kept it, and while that doesn't take a lot to do, this one made me come back again and again. It's creative, the atmosphere it creates is truly unique, and it shows a horrific perversion of the human mind, both in the VIPs and the Front Man himself.The VIPs were okay. I thought the character design and writing was spot on for what they wanted to portray, but the actors were definitely sub-par. Seems like everybody has said this already though, so I don't need to say much about it.Definitely a 9/10 for me. I'll come back and rewatch it when season 2 (hopefully) airs.

title: Squid Game
review:
There are three types of human relationships that squid game characters have.Type 1. The relationship between Deoksu (101) and his gang to obey by power.Type 2. Human relationships (218 and 1), such as Sang-woo (218), Il-nam (1), that give others to benefit from human relationships (218 and 1) succeeded in society, are intelligent, and elite)
Type 3. Ki Hoon (456), Abdul Ali (199), sae byuk (67) and Ji Young (240) have pure trust (less social experience or unemployed)The best way to relate was to play the 4th game.A. saebyuk-Jiyoung, Deoksu-His subordinates were a team of the same type.Saebyuk and Jiyoung lived a difficult life as North Korean defectors and killers in society, but Jiyoung sacrifices for the saebyuk that opened her hand for the first time (Confrontation between Type 3)Deoksu and his subordinates usually work together, but they have no choice but to turn right away in extreme situations where they live only when they kill each other (Confrontation between Type 1)
Deoksu's betrayal by his subordinates before entering the squid game immediately shows how easy human relationships are to be betrayed in extreme situations.B. Abdul Ali-Sangwoo, Ilnam-Kihoon were a team of different types of people.In the confrontation between Abdul Ali (199) and Sangwoo (218), Abdul Ali trusts Sangwoo until the end, but Sangwoo betrays and wins (Type 2 wins against Type 3).Sang-woo (218) gives Ali Abdul a bus fare, but I think he has changed in the same way as Type 2 as he has experienced a loss if he acts like 199 while adapting to society.-Ilnam (1) and Kihoon (456) are people who have lived opposite lives even in their numbers.Il-nam (No. 1) meets and plays with people like Ki-hoon (No. 456), who already makes a lot of money and feels demonstrated in life as he grows old, and gives no return, and feels joy in pure human relationships.Ki-hoon (456) gives a favor to Il-nam (1) and impresses the writing so that Il-nam loses on purpose (Type 3 wins Type 2)Ilnam (1) is a successful person in life, and he has lived in Type 2 way, and he seemed to think that it was right.Social life, socially high command and a lot of income people who think we should act in ways such as type 1 or type 2.I think I've experienced that type of people win while playing squid for a long time.The scene that shows this appears in the scene where vip bet 101 or 218 times as a favorite.Ki Hoon (456) was a person who overturned all of the above thoughts.-VIP didn't pick Kihoon (456) as the favorite.In the final, when Ki-hoon (456) tried to give up the money without stabbing him, Sang-woo was moved by Ki-hoon and committed suicide by admitting that his beliefs lost to Ki-hoon.Ilnam(1) has lost his mindset while playing the game.He lost to the type of person he thought was stupid who had stepped on to get a high position throughout his life.The last time Ilnam called Ki-hoon to play the game in the last episode seems to have tried to discuss Ki-hoon's reversal of his thoughts for the last time.Kihoon (456) met Ilnam at the end and played a game, and asked Ilnam, "I won now, right?"
While playing the squid game, Ki-hoon showed ilnam that his thoughts were wrong as a result, but Ki-hoon doesn't seem to know that he did.It was a series that allowed people to reconsider human relationships by showing that people like Ki Hoon, who give trust and favor in no return, beat others.

title: Squid Game
review: Although I don't usually like violent weird fictional series I would like to comment on this one, which I found to be quite good if you watch it as a metaphor of the financial game, the squid game is in my view the financial game and I would like to give some hints of why I think this. There may be some spoilers ahead, so don't read further if you don't want to know them.In the series we are introduced to some characters that have already played the game, or similar games like gambling (most of the new players are highly indebted) or are just very poor people that will be invited to play the big game, which comes with the much needed reward, the big money.The gameThe game is the financial game and we see the players being part of it trying to get the big price but dying in the way because of that. Nobody has been forced to play the game but nobody knows what the game is about, and as soon as they are in the game they can't leave it if is not by a majority deciding so. And this is the big question asked for the game designers when participants are showed that the game will play with their jobs, their families subsistence and, in sum, with their lives."Knowing this, do you accept the game or do you refuse it? "Nicely, after the first deadly round the vote is tied, and the last voter, the player number one, which later on we will know is a game designer playing for fun, the only one on the game from the elite, the only one that deeply knows about the game and may by himself stop it, votes to stop the game giving to the poor folks the chance to live a decent live far from the deadly game. But the game never stops, so most of the players return to it when given a new chance to win or die.The island, the leader and the policemanThe game is corrupted, so it has to be played in an island, a tax haven, outside the law. This is a parallel plot ran by two brothers, one of them running the game, the leader, that would be the corrupt lawyer or the broker that we learn that already got his money share when he won a previous edition of the games, and a policeman, the law, that manages to get there looking for him as the leader is his brother, and that sadly is being killed by the corrupted brother being unable to expose the plot to the justice.The secondary playersBetween the players we find some of the social archetypes. There is the gangster, used to play by his own wild rules but without the skills and the knowledge to win in the big game, the immigrants, political and non political, playing with their disadvantages and being cheated and murdered, people with family traumas for whom the game means nothing now, the broker who already played the game in the real life before and failed, and who knows that the game has to been played dirty if you want to win, but even like this, you may always loose, ...The old man and the main characterFinally, between the players, there are two of them especially interesting, the first one and the last one. The first one is, as we find out at the end, a game designer that is so implied in it that cannot be like the other VIPs, gambling and watching from the outside, but has to play. His reward is not the money but the act of playing itself. The last one is all of us, is the TV watcher watching all of them, watching the game and being fascinated for it but at the same time refusing it, not willing to fall in its trap, not wanting to be mean, trying not to play dirty but at the same time doing nothing in front of the horror. This is why the old man takes an interest on him and there is a wonderful scene in the game of marbles where he sets up a situation inviting to the honest player to cheat, and he, the honest hero, cheats to save his life knowing that the old man will be unfairly killed for this. And then is when the old man gives him his last marble as reward, because the old man has now win his own game, he has finally won his own reward that isn't the money but knowing that everybody has a price and that everybody would have done what he possibly has done to become who he is. He can get rid of his guilt and he can leave the game as the real winner. However, when the hero wins the final game and may be proclaimed as winner, he refuses to win, he tries unsuccessfully to leave the game giving up the reward, and goes like this after that, being impossible for him to do anything with a money that becomes dirty as it has been earned cheating a poor old man who was killed because of it. He and the old man are on a similar situation now, both are rich thanks to the misery of others, and both feel guilty about it. So, in a desperately bid to get rid of his own culpability, of his own failure, the old man reveals him who he is, which is for some time effective, because our hero learns that nobody died because of him cheating and that he was the one cheated by the old man, so he may feel innocent again and enjoy the reward, until this falls again in front of the truth, revealed now by the recruiting scene of new potential gamers in the metro. Nobody who knows and has played the game may be innocent anymore.

title: Squid Game
review: This one kept me watching. Great characters. Interesting, if very dark story. I didn't find myself rooting for any single person. They were all flawed, damaged, even downright pathetic at times. Especially the "protagonist", which is a term I use very loosely here. He's not likeable. He leeches off of his mother, he takes money intended to buy a birthday present and dinner for his 10 year old daughter and gambles it away. Again, he wasn't likeable. But he was a well written character who at times I almost found myself sympathizing with, only for that sympathy to fade with another cowardly action.There is no objective good guy, with the closest one being the undercover cop, though even he acted questionably and reckless.Not every story needs a good guy though. I am fine with this. In fact, I applaud this series from breaking the "hero of the story" trope. Every single character seems to have a compelling reason for being where they are.In several ways, this series reminded me of Alice in Borderland, which I personally think was better written and one of my favourite series in this particular genre. Though this one was still a good series and well worth watching overall.Cue forward to the VIP scenes. As mentioned before, that could have been done much better. I don't know where they found these guys, but none of them were convincing. Their downright atrocious acting knocked down my rating by 2 stars.I can handle the occasional bad actor. I honestly don't mind when it's a single person in a role that isn't too important, but these VIPs filled the screen for far longer than their talent as actors should have permitted. Especially the old man with his 69 obsession. His lines were bad, his delivery, worse. Whoever he is, I hope that was the last time I saw him on a screen. He wouldn't have been out of place in Troll 2.I want to end this on a positive note. Honestly, the story was really good. The plot twist with player 1 is incredible and one I personally didn't expect, even if I had some suspicions. Towards the end, the main character has grown as a person and becomes someone I can almost respect. Which is quite an accomplishment on its own.But he should have gotten on the plane.

title: Squid Game
review: Squid game has set an extremely high bar for other shows of this genre. It is intense. It is raw. It is an emotional roller coaster. This is a masterpiece throughout. I actually felt that the poor VIP acting was a good metaphor of modern Hollywood when compared to the incredible performances by some of the main cast members here. I sincerely hope they continue the series in the same style and it does not get the SAW franchise treatment.But Episode 6 - Gganbu.... So powerful. Possibly the best single episode of a show I have ever seen.More, more, more please.

title: Squid Game
review: It was fun, but the show falls back on usual Korean story tropes (ie forced deaths to make "cool" sacrifices) , the acting by the VIPs was so laughibly bad and cringy that it almost tanked the whole show, and some stuff is stupid and makes no sense at all.Examples (spoilers!)1. The players keep acting like they can win the game together and get out of there together with the money, again and again. It's made 100% clear that they either can't stop playing until one person is left alive, or they can end things with a majority vote but then don't get the money. No one ever mentions this again or acklowedges that anyone they bond with will die if they want that money.2. They all left the game and then choose to come back, knowing the above... but a husband and wife joined again. They tried to make it a shocking and surprising thing that this poor couple are made to face each other to the death, but by choosing to come back they knew that one of them would have to die. Really dumb!3. The first time when they quit they say the accumulated money will go to the families of the deseased. When they return that money is still in the piggy bank and they continue from where they left off.4. The missing brothers stuff is in the goshiwon and it seems like rent was skipped for a month, so the cop brother says he will pay the rent and looks through his stuff, goes looking for him because of that card. Later we see in a file that he won the game years ago, and it seems he's been working as the front man for a good long time too. Um...didn't he just go missing recently?4. They gave my fav character a super cheap death. Cmon, random exploding glass took her out? She's there to play the games and no one notices she's been impaled or offers some medical attention so she can compete still...when they say it's all fair? How did they know there damn stupid exploding glass trick would not take everyone out and end the games by mistake? It was just a set up for that 3 in the sleeping area with knives scene, but was too forced.5. They took all interest and moral dilemma out if the ending by neatly killing off everyone, keeping the good guys hand s clean, and making the other guy a clear villain.6. The main character gets stabbed twice in the final fight but carries on fairly easily, but the other guy gets bit in the foot and that's it...becomes completely defenseless after that. The whole ending after that was very forced.7. The red hair thing was a little stupid. As was the case off money for the old lady and child - looks cool but how is she gonna use that or explain it when putting it in a bank? Her son is missing for fraud and the cops already visited her. In the same vein - him becomg a sudden multibillionaire didn't attract any attention from the tax office?8. When he got off the plane at the end: we went full circle and killed the character development because the last thing he does is impulsive, prob gonna get him killed (no way he can take on this shadow group with red hair and some cash - he's easily dead) and he lied and failed his daughter. Again.9. They didn't tie off a few things. The Morse code thing went nowhere if I'm not mistaken. The guy didn't do anything to get that mom back from N Korea.10. Also, cop guy infiltrates stupidly easily - and his iphone battery life is AMAZING. No way there's a charging cable laying around in a facility were no phones are allowed. Even Mr head honcho has to use a land line.11. Will normal people playing games really randomly all out try to kill each other at night? They say they provide less food to stoke tension, but there was enough for everyone if that group didn't cut in line for seconds. No way they'd know that would happen. And it certainly wouldn't guarantee a bloodbath. It's normal people in debt, not hardened criminals (apart from the one guy).And that's about what I remember. It was fun, but a little stupid too. It started very strong and could have been GREAT, but the writing needed tightening up and less reliance on formulaic tropes.

title: Squid Game
review: I'm Korean, and people around me kept telling me to watch this show so I decided to try it. Definitely exceeded my expectations. It brought much more emotional attachment that many Western shows, and I liked how the show wasn't very predictable. For example, I loved OBX but it felt a little repetitive to the point I started watching it more for the characters than the plot itself. However, this show really did well in terms of both the character development and plot.Also, I've seen reviews saying the Netflix subtitles were inaccurate. But idk, I thought it was well written (as a bilingual person) I loved the dubbings too bc the voices really matched.Lastly, to address the VIP scene, many people said they were poor actors and had cringe lines.I think the lines embodied the American culture pretty well for a Korean crew. At this point, yall should be thankful it wasn't worse. Also, since not a lot of foreigners live in Korea, it would have been difficult to pick up actual actors for the show.

title: Squid Game
review: It's disturbing but all the more entertaining for it. I rarely watch series with a plot, let alone that fast (took me less than 4 days, which is super unusual for me). Read some reviews saying there was no character development but I will have to disagree. All major character change from ep 1 to their last respective scene. Some scenes were very emotional as well, ep 6 had me sobbing. The acting by the VIP's was a bit off-putting but ultimately didn't bother me as much. I loved the games too, being of Korean descent. Only the 5th game was somewhat out of order and dragged a bit. The additional storylines around the games made it even more real, somehow. There are some open ends which have me looking forward to the 2nd season.

And after seeing the death of 455 players, it is understandable why he didn't choose to break his daughter's new family in LA (which can be considered as paradise) but come back to Hell Joseon as a new human-being (when ppl change their hair color, it means that they want to be a new them) to maybe get revenge for his friend or change the whole system of the game ^^? Can't wait to know what will happen next so please release season 2 the sooner the better!!!!

title: Squid Game
review: This movie is sooooo overrated, it's a blatant plagiarism from Japanese movies like "As the Gods will", "Liar Game", "Friend Game", and the final twist is a piece of a popular series name Saw.The director of the film even stated that As The Gods Will was created in the 2010s, after his initial idea for Squid Game, but if he had to say it, he would say he did it first.Seriously? He make a movie that has a lot of stuff copied from movies that came out years ago and say he made it first by his idea?!? You think audiences are stupid?You create something after someone else, you have to make it different otherwise you are just a copycat of other people's work and effort. You can't just copied and say "I made it first because I had the idea in mind first." It's ridiculous!Stealing other people's work and make it your own it's dirty and unacceptable in the modern world, a really talented, self-respecting director would definitely never do that.

title: Squid Game
review: 1. The red jumpsuit of the numbers - symbolizes they are like a colony of red ants. They work together but when one person is gone, it won't be a big deal and they can easily be replaced by another ant or in their case, another number. I think them being a red ant instead of being a black ant (apart from looking friendly or light) also insinuates that they're the more aggressive ones (they're the ones that kill off people) since red ant's bite is harsher than a black ant's.2. The masks - symbolize that the numbers work for the players but the irony is also that they don't WORK for the players. They are not controlled by the players because the players are not the ones actually in charge of the games.3. The ladders in the lobby - symbolize social hierarchy that we need to climb as we progress to the society. As the players move to the games, they climb up the ladder, meaning they're reaching a higher hierarchy because they are gaining more money through playing.4. The ribboned / present-like casket - the art director said that this symbolizes that the creator views themselves as a god that has given the players the chance to change their life. Their money was a present from them and their death is also a present from them.This show just have the perfect tone, pace, setting, and depth.

title: Squid Game
review: The show has a plot that focuses on multiple people who are in a financial crisis, that engage in a death game with the last person standing winning a lot of cash. The way the games are done builds up anticipation of what is to come next , leaving audiences on the edge of fear and anxiety until eventually it unfolds into shock , as they see that in these games no life is spared. As for the actors , every actor does a great job of playing each character that has their own unique character traits . Overall , in my honest opinion everything was executed wonderfully from the music , the cinematography , plot , characters , and much more. Truly , if you haven't watch the show yet I promise that if you do watch it , you will be stunned by it and will be left wanting to see more.

title: Squid Game
review:
Squid Game is one of the most popular TV series of 2021 so I decided I would try it out. The show completely captured me when it came to the drama between the characters and the intensity of the games. I recommend this show if you're interested in a fast-paced, drama series that will leave you on the edge of your seat and will make you think at the same time. This show is relentless and graphic so it's not for the faint of heart. For nine episodes, Hwang Dong-hyuk captured many facets of humanity and the world as we know it.Characters:I enjoyed many of the characters and the acting was phenomenal. At first I criticized Gi-Hun for being a gambler but as the series went on it showed his tragic downfall and the lack of job security in South Korea. I don't know much about South Korea but I imagined it to be somewhat more prosperous than America. No, everywhere is cruel, I learned, as the world showed Ali's kindness taken advantage of and the ending bet with the man in the snow. I loved Sae-Byeok and I cried when her friend gave up her life for her. I even felt some remorse for Player 218, or Sangwoo, when he was lying in the rain, completely jaded, the rain crashing down on him on the realization on what he did. Each character has their moment and I felt for each one of them.**
Themes:
The themes are what make this show beautiful. Gi-Hun and Sang-woo being foils of each others was well-executed. I kept asking myself the question, is Sang-woo wrong? He had to kill those people to survive. He had to push the man in glass hopskotch or the others wouldn't have made it. He did what he had to do to survive, and yet we critcize him because we think it's what we wouldn't have done. But we would we to survive? And then the war of poverty and tragedy with all the characters was honest but heart-breaking to see. Ali still had to break his morals and hurt a man to receive his salary for his family. 067 or Sae-Byeok pickpocketed because she had nothing else to resort to - after all, she was an illegal alien from North Korea. We don't know why Sang-woo fought (he had only his mother left) but he wanted to restore himself instead of admit he was not the pride of his hometown.**
Criticisms
Many plot threads go nowhere. Doctor sub-plot was pointless, although I was still chilled by the Front-man's lack of respect for the Player's body. Also, the Morse Code wasn't mentioned again unless it was relevant to the Doctor subplot.Jun-ho effortlessly managing to get into Squid Island. Would have been interesting if they had intentionally let him raid it and kill him afterward (after all, who can be blamed if everyone remains anon. This man broke the rules so many times but the most he got was a slap on the wrist? What is the point of the rules for the employees then if the only enforced rules are the masks?The plot twist with Jun-ho finding out the Front Man was his brother. An extreme plot hole considering the beginning (mentioned by mrloletter) when Jun-ho was paying his brother's rent for only a month. His brother wasn't missing that long. But then later we find out that he won in 2015(?), so 5 years before the show began. So I guess the brother is a bit older than him but holy crap the Front Man looks considerably older. I didn't really understand the plot twist. Maybe the Front-Man will feel bad that he killed his brother? It showed that he did feel some remorse and that he was willing to save his brother. Since we don't understand the Front Man's motivations this scene was very odd.The VIPs. The acting was horrible and ruined my immersion in the show.The Ending
Personally I really loved the ending. Many don't like how Gi-Hun turns into a strawberry but I liked the symbolism, albeit it was way too obvious. He had lost his mother, explaning why he didn't go straight to his daughter. Even though he had won he still felt like he had failed. That he was too late. The worst feeling in the world. He felt like he was a horrible person and didn't know what to say to his daughter (remember that he still hit her stepfather and never explained it to her). Even with him calling the number and saying that "I'm a threat" was a bit interesting since it leads on to a Season 2, and also shows he still has some fight left in him.Player One being the founder was an odd twist but I still liked it since it exposed who he was as a person and his attitudes toward the poor (being deserving). Playet One was honest at the games telling Gi-Hun, his gganbu, his reasons, his motivations, and even his greatest weaknesses. He still loved Gi-Hun in some way that I still liked his character (even though he's a horrible person).Overall I'm excited for Season 2 and what to come. Squid Game is absolutely amazing!

title: Squid Game
review: I did enjoy first three episodes for setting up the tone, but past those show drags on, I don't think story was fleshed out beyond there's this room and people play games in it and if they lose they die. Ending is also.lackluster, you expect it to reveal the motives for this game but the answer you get is unsatisfying to say the least.Also, from the ending episode seems like they're setting up for another season, but frankly, I don't think there's much left to tell in regards to the story, and I fear like with most decent series it will devolve into The Walking Dead.variant of the Squid Game, where they renew for the new seasons and only then start working on the story and I doubt that's enough time to write a captivating story, nonetheless, I wish them good luck. For first three episodes alone, I'd say it's worth a watch.

title: Squid Game
review: Normally, I'm not a big fan of Korean series and music. But here I have to say well done to the director and the actors of this series. I'm not a big fan of series in general, because I never get hooked and get bored very easily. So I am someone who watches a lot of film and hardly ever a series. This time around is the first time I've "LOVED" a series and hooked it from start to finish. The story is original and it feels like a kind of hunger game, with characters who are in dire straits and who fight until the end to win a huge amount of money. The fact that the series is really different from all the other series is that it has its own universe, its own setting. Watching this series is like a drug. We are addicted and we want more, we want to know more things. We easily get attached to the characters because we pity them enough. And I think it's a good lesson in morale, this series certainly represents, a little exaggerated, today's society. I can only advise you. If I had to give this series a rating, it would be 19/20 because season 2. We can't wait !!

title: Squid Game
review: On the base, Squid Game appears to be a standard Korean horror/thriller we have been slowly getting more accustomed to in the west over the past few years, however beneath the surface is a very deep, complex and scarily real message that is incredibly relevent in these troubling times.Without spoiling anything, this series is certainly worth sticking with through the slower parts, as the ending and message is extremely powerful. Worryingly, I feel the complexity of the message may mean it is lost on the average viewer, but left me deep in though and reflection upon its completion.I'm sure in the years to come this series will be looked back on as the benchmark for complex and contrasted story telling, and even though it is extremely popular now, in years to come it's message may be more appreciated.

title: Squid Game
review: This is a horror story, and I'm not normally a huge fan of the genre, which could make my read on it a bit uncharitable. However, it seems to present itself early on as more than just a horror story, which in my opinion it ultimately is not.Most of the plot outside of the titular games ends up culminating in a couple of twists that somehow both are predictable and make little to no sense in the context of the rest of the story.There is a lot to like here - stunning visuals, an eerie soundtrack, and plenty of solid performances in the early going. If you're in it for the survival horror of it all, this might be an entertaining thrill ride, and that's okay. For me, outside of a few well-delivered character moments early on, it played as a sloppily constructed piece of visual storytelling which spends most of its runtime on overlong, ultra violent, empty spectacle.

title: Squid Game
review: I was honestly excited when I started the series, primarily because it was blowing up on social media. It did sound similar to Alice in Borderland (which had turned out be one my favourite series of all time), but I wanted to find out why it took off in the first place, when Alice in Borderland didn't receive nearly as much attention.Up until the tug-of-war episode, it seemed to be going okay. I think, for me, it peaked at the tug-of-war episode. But after that the whole series turned into a snooze fest. I mean, oh my god, it turned out to be so mind numbingly boring. And some areas were so blatantly copied from Alice in Borderland that I was shocked this series did not get slapped with a copyright. Ugh, such a waste of time. Honestly, if you've seen Alice in Borderland, don't bother watching Squid Game. The comparison is inevitable and it will leave behind a bitter taste.

title: Squid Game
review: It's obvious that the idea of the games involving the lives of humans has appeared more than once in TV shows. Although the director has confirmed that the idea was planned many years ago, it's questionable that originality is one of its strengths. However, this series has made a different approach to the category, and for that reason I can understand its impact.The mixture of show and survival makes this story special. Involving emotions in tragic games transforms fear into treason, empathy into selfishness and hate into pain. Something that is usually complex to achieve. Social context plays an essential role in the series. Knowing the personal situations of the participants creates a vital link between the game and society. Best aspects? Feelings. Everything that this series could make you feel has a purpose and a reason. Almost every action of the characters is explainable in a certain way but also leaves you room for doubts and predictions about the next move. You won't get bored with the episodes, which is a priority among thrillers.Drawbacks? As I see it, the games ended faster than I was expecting. When you are risking your life, time seems to pass really slowly and in the series it happened all the opposite. For instance, I would have tried to enlarge the game scenes in the episodes. It's true that with this improvement your are risking the total timing, and perhaps it could become tiring, but that would be the best idea to take advantage of such a great plot. It would also have given the chance to extend a bit on the story of some characters that are relevant in the development of the series, which could be seen as one of the negative aspects, the lack of depth.All in all, it's such an excellent production, and I strongly recommend it without doubts.

title: Squid Game
review: The concept and idea of the game is pretty cool, but there are too many holes in the plot to be able to enjoy it as much as I should.Why did the old man vote to end it after the first game, when he was behind it all?Where did all the prize money and money to keep staff and facilities etc come from? Did the VIP's really sponsor with this amount of cash?Who are these people working there accepting all of this?How can these competitions have lasted for over a decade without any of them getting the story out?How could the organ harvester do this, with the trap doors in special furnaces etc. Without it being known by the front man?The idea of deathly competitions with child games are quite thought out and brilliant, except that there are games that really are not child games.However when trying to create the reason and background for all of it, it just feels flat and like a quick fix.The VIP's acting/script is just as horrible and flat as the story behind it all.I can still recommend people to watch it though!It still is quite exciting at times and the relationships are pretty well thought out!

title: Squid Game
review:
I found the excessive amount of violence and extended shooting scenes completely unnecessary
specially for a 2021 production. Was that all really necessary? I fast forwarded most of them. Surely, the message 'people will do anything for money' could have been demonstrated and communicated in a more smart and artistic way. Squid Game really made me think that movies and TV shows should be regulated on the content and duration of violent scenes, to prevent viewers from adopting violent behaviors themselves and become trigger happy. I didn't see the value at all in showing hundreds of people been shot for minutes. The violence in this production was so raw, it was just distracting until the very end and ruined a potentially good script.

title: Squid Game
review: Watched the show in 2 days, i must admit, it is in fact quite bingeable. However, I'm confused as to what i saw versus the reception by the audience, as "the most amazing and smart netflix-show ever created". Did we watch the same show?Overall, the show is decent. It's not original, which it is (hopefully) not trying to be, the execution is solid (for the most part). Some of the games were pretty interesting, s.a. The dalgona candy game or the squid game.However, the show lacks a lot of development, considering for how long its is, and has major plot problems: the storyline about dissection of the organs suddenly discontinued, i thought that was the whole point of these games? To gather a lot of bodies in order to dissect them and sell the organs. Nope, apparently not. Apparently, it's because some old man was bored on his death bead. In fact, nothing in the show was really explained, everyone's motivation seemed unclear and illogical in regard to what they were actually doing. I couldn't care for any of the characters, couldn't care for their death or their life or dynamic, couldn't care for the story of the two brothers, couldn't care for their interactions because they were all super super shallow.Conversations were super awkward, boring, dragged on for too long paired with a lot of severe and uncomfortable overacting by the actors. Tried to be extremely melodramatic in parts where it wasn't called for.Many other details didn't make sense or were just super unrealistic.The vips took the whole cake and ruined the show for good, but then the ending itself managed to suck even more.Well...i would definitely cut this show some slack, if it wasn't so well recieved. Come on guys, it's an okay show but definitely not the best Netflix show ever. People are calling it genius for foreshadowing the character's death when i could tell you 10 other shows that did it in the same way, as it is a common storytelling technique (and not original at that)I'm starting to think, people are pushing this show just because it is a Korean production, trying to make it out to be the best movie industry.Anyways, don't expect too much from this show, it's definitely overhyped and I'm glad i watched it early on, when it wasn't too popular yet.

title: Squid Game
review: The series had my attention gripped tight from episodes 1 - 7. If I would have stopped right there I would have given it a 9/10, but then episodes 8 and 9 happen.I findd Gi-Hun being mad at Sang-Woo for sacrificing the glasses guy just a dumb way to create conflict between the characters. Gi-Hun betrays his friend because he saved his life??? Gi-Hun just doesn't work as a main character, at the very end he barely grows as a character. Imagine how great it would have been if Sang-Woo had won the squid game and then have to live with the fact that he killed his friend, it would have made for a very dark yet introspective finale.I have mixed feelings towards the old man being the host of the games, it kinda ruins the Gganbu scene, but at the same time I like how deranged and twisted was his justification for starting the games.Gi-Hun leaving the airport to stop the games instead of visiting his daughter is kinda lame. It just felt like a cheap sequel-bait ending. Season 2 will likely be the typical "small resistance group trying to take down the opressors", and I'm tired of stories taking the same turn over and over again.I get that I'm complaining just because thigs didn't end the way I wanted, but don't you think it would have been more interesting if we had gotten a darker and conclusive ending rather than the one we got, which I think is kinda generic?

title: Squid Game
review: The first 6 episodes are quite strong but it unfortunately gets progressively worse afterwards. The awkward acting by the VIPs introduced in episode 7 was immersion breaking but could have been overlooked given that they are not a major part of the show. Otherwise the episode is still fine and provides satisfying conclusions to the stories of a few supporting characters.Episode 8 concludes the police investigation side plot which in my opinion was the weakest part of the show. We spend a lot of time with the young detective infiltrating the facility but we never get to know him very well, never see him grapple with his emotions or share his motivations with any of the other major characters. Here his story just sort of fizzles out. In the end he has done his job as a plot device revealing some of the evil organization's secrets to the viewer but hasn't actually accomplished anything. The other main characters never even learn he was there in the first place.Episode 8 also kills off Sae-Byeok who is either the show's most prominent side character or its least important main. Unfortunately it's a weak ending for her arc. She gets established as a resourceful badass in the first three episodes smuggling in a knife and crawling through air vents, but ends up being wounded through sheer dumb luck, then killed in a way that further builds the enmity between protagonist Gi-Hun and his childhood friend Sang-Woo. Her character seemed destined for more: If not survival and a reunion with her brother then at least a death more meaningful and less contrived.The ninth episode finally is maybe the weakest of the show. Our main character wins the games as expected and somewhat understandably spends a year wallowing in depression after his traumatic experiences. In a final plot twist it is revealed that Il-Nam, the old man seemingly suffering from dementia whom he has helped throughout the games up to his death (which it turns out he has faked), actually was the big bad all along, the organizer and host of the death games hundreds of people perished in. This obviously recontextualizes every interaction with him we have previously witnessed and in my opinion diminishes his story quite a bit. The story of an old man not willing to wait around for his death may be a bit of a cliche but it was still sad and well executed. As a villain Il-Nam is just another degenerate rich guy little more interesting than any of the other VIPs.Overall the show still has some very strong moments with episode 6 probably the best it ever gets. The final third still leaves a bad taste in my mouth though and brings down what maybe could have been a masterpiece.

title: Squid Game
review: "Squid Game" does a great job of showing the effect of money on an individual's life worth and kindness. Director Hwang is able to convey this theme to the viewers through a diverse cast of characters who are introduced with varying levels of morality, but all share extreme financial instability. The characters enter a game where there is a 40 million dollar cash prize for a sole winner, with a gruesome twist of players getting killed if they are eliminated. Director Hwang created this scenario to portray "capitalist society" and "the extreme competition of life". Despite this the characters insist on continuing the game, as they believe their lives in the outside world are forfeit, with no chances to earn enough money to lead a dignified life. Here "Squid Game" does a good job illustrating how desperate the poor can be. However the belief that a life with money will bring happiness is something that's tested throughout the series.The audience then learns very quickly what kind of character thrives the most, as those willing to sacrifice others seem to win the games with ease while the more morally inclined struggle, having to choose between their own benefit or helping other players. Even the main character, Gi-hun, who is introduced to us as affectionate for others, comes to a point in the games where he decides to take advantage of his friend, only to feel terrible guilt. This demonstrates that in such competitive circumstances, good individuals begin to compromise their morality, losing people close to them on the way. The idea that the prize will bring closure becomes even more blurrier.Gi-hun survives, and is one of the two people to make it to the final game . The other being his childhood best friend who progressed by betraying other players. In a fight to the death Gi-hun refuses to kill his friend, who ends up comminting suicide due to guilt. Gi-hun wins the 40 million, but with no sense of meaning or kindness anymore willingly spends the rest of his life in poverty refusing to spend a single cent. Squid Game makes us ask if achieving success alone in an individualistic and competitive society is worth the people we already have around us. In this regard it does a great job as a social commentary as it shows the desperation of the poor, how morality can be compromised, and the guilt that comes with taking advantage of others.Project: Gabriel extracts deeper meaning from a TV show based on winning money for a series of dangerous games such as the desperation of the poor, the tension between money and happiness, and ultimately.

title: Squid Game
review: Just as the title reads. This series is an emotional ride on every single level, and I believe there is so much an actor can convey in a scene that transcends language. After finishing the series I checked out the English dubbed version and it was painful to watch; all of that powerful tone, inflection, emotion - gone and replaced by poorly-acted robotic American voices. These actors are extremely talented and you deserve to experience their performance to the fullest extent possible. Watch the Korean version - it will enrich your viewing experience greatly.The hype around this show was so intense that I went in assuming my expectations wouldn't be met - and they were far exceeded. It's difficult for me to put into words how fantastic I thought this series was, but it wow'ed me on every level. The sets are absolutely mesmerizing, the score is haunting, the acting is superb, the characters are flawed and complex, and the storyline(s) are very well thought-out. I keep finding myself returning to Netflix/YouTube to rewatch scenes from the show because they struck me so deeply. I hope for a 2nd season, I'd love to watch regardless of which direction it goes in!! Absolutely mind blowing show.I would use caution if you are sensitive to death & violence. Even if you're not terribly sensitive either, to be honest. This show doesn't hold back!

title: Squid Game
review: I decided to watch Squid Game under strange circumstances. I live in a small town in Eastern Europe. One day, while shopping in a local supermarket, I was approached by two young people (school-age), who asked me if I wanted to play a Squid Game. I had heard of the Netflix hit, so instantly made the association, but ultimately, my reply was: sorry, don't have time for silly games. The moment we parted ways, however, I knew *what* I was going to watch that evening..I can only guess why youngsters like Squid Game. Is it finding strength in numbers? A desire to be part of a clandestine network? Gory scenes one would find in many a video game? A prospect of "easy" money that challenges the traditional, education-based route to success? I don't know.For me, Squid Game is first and foremost a vivid reminder about human nature that hasn't really changed much since ancient times. Generally in life, but especially in a free-for-all, expect lots of backstabbing and underhand dealings. People will lie, change allegiances and exploit others' weaknesses, including their sense of morality, to further own interests. Not everyone is like that, of course, or not like that all the time. Squid Game illustrates this point pretty well imho, just as it does force people to think about things in life that matter the most: is it money? Family? Adrenalin? Love?

title: Squid Game
review: Leader in downloads and viewing. The series that overshadowed many Hollywood projects. I couldn't not watch The Squid Game! But he wasn't in any particular hurry, although a high-quality version appeared almost immediately after the release. What were the expectations? Well, I was expecting something bloody, like "Survival Games", or "Hunger Games". Of course, with Korean specifics. In general, I started watching, assuming in advance that I would see a high-quality spectacle!My expectations were justified! What pleased me the most was that the series had meaning, and not just stupid gore. Yes, yes, it is! Once again, I was convinced that there are problems in Korea too. But nevertheless... And the main of those very problems is the stratification of society. There are many very poor, and at the same time there is a snickering stratum. This is familiar, right?There are many central events in the series. It is possible, however, to single out the main point. It's Song Ki-hoon, not a particularly pretty guy who's in big trouble. By coincidence, Gi-hun observes a certain game in which there is a large cash prize and in which the same poor fellows as our hero appear. But what will be the price?It immediately became clear that this film is quite violent. Well, expended never repels. What surprised me is that the characters are exaggerated (don't forget that the series is Korean) and even more, they are all charismatic! Remember the heroes! Song Gi-hoon, grandpa, thief girl, gangster, Pakistani... Well, or almost none, because after all, many faces were purely Korean...I'm not as observant as some of the individuals who have previously viewed Squid. Therefore, I would not have guessed about some moments, honestly. But we have well-wishers, I won't watch, who spoiled almost the entire viewing for me, thereby reducing the "tastyness" of the spectacle. No, in any case, I liked the series and there were still surprises.What else to highlight? Perhaps I will note the games themselves, which were invented by the organizers of the show. I don't even know which one is highlighted. I liked everything!Why did the series become secret? Popular and well-known even when broadcasting Russian football matches? It's just organic in everything, there are no redundant episodes, the action is dynamic, and it's never boring to watch. The shape of employees with triangles, circles and squares on the face, in general, will soon become well distributed and really hype! There are cult films, serials less often. "Brigade", "Game of Thrones" ... Perhaps I don't remember more. "Playing Squid" can hardly be attributed to this category, although who knows, after a few years, let's say, maybe the point of therapeutic treatment ...I look forward to the second season, which will most likely be. Of course, there are a lot of new features in acceptable completeness. I recommend watching this high-quality Korean series!

title: Squid Game
review: Why can't we tear ourselves away from watching this series? The series has a very correct structure - one series - one game. There are no episodes where only conversations are shown, for example. There is always some action that keeps you in suspense.The picture is colorful. Let's start with the fact that all the actors (participants of the game) are dressed in green suits. The location they are in always changes colors. In the first game - some colors, in the second - others, etc.The plot itself is quite new for Russia, I don't remember such series.Koreans are a very expressive people in themselves, and this expressiveness hyperbolizes all the emotions they experience during the series. For example, fear of death, anger, hatred. The viewer feels all this very well.I would especially like to highlight the negative character Dogsu (I think that's his name). A very cool actor who aroused the contempt of all the viewers, turned out to be white and fluffy in life (take a look at his Instagram).The ending is quite unexpected, the series claims for the second season unequivocally.In general, it's definitely worth watching! The series so far has 1 season with 9 episodes that risk being watched in 1 night.

title: Squid Game
review: An interesting plot, shows the real life of people who love to play, are ready for anything for the sake of money. The protagonist wants to earn money to provide for his daughter, whom he wants to see more often than he can at the moment.

title: Squid Game
review: Netflix has released a new Korean series about a deadly rivalry between people - "The Squid Game". A man in a black mask gathered 456 people in a hangar on the island. All of them are in need, someone has lost all their property, and some also owe the bank. The prize, $40 million, will go to those who make it to the end. In total, participants will have to go through six competitions, the plots of which are taken from children's games.This series seems to be exploiting the hackneyed theme of survival games again, but it has several features. For starters, The Squid Game is really exciting - the games are made very cool and on a large scale. There are many players here, however, with each round their number will fall, but nevertheless, the viewer is immediately offered a huge set of characters. To make it easier, each of them is assigned a profile that they play out: a wise old man, a ruthless bandit, a good-natured migrant from Pakistan. The heroes here resemble game avatars with sets of preset characteristics.
